now for some background
chaos engineering the discipline has
been around for nearly a decade as you
all know
put simply it is about injecting random
and unpredictable faults to simulate
real world events and verify system
behavior
it is typically practiced by sres and
ops folks as part of game days on
production or production like
environments
that said
the cloud native paradigm has changed
the way the apps are built tested
shipped deployed and maintained
there are a lot of changes in the way
infrastructure is viewed and managed too
if you take a look at this slide
the pyramid here
talks about the several layers
at which resiliency needs to be enforced
you have the platform infrastructure the
kubernetes services
you have a lot of tooling from the cloud
native landscape that you pulled in to
help with seamless delivery and
maintenance of your
services
you have direct application dependencies
like message queues databases etc and
then you have your actual application
with its user facing services middleware
backend services etc
and the surface area for failures is
just that much more in a cloud native
environment
so this has brought in a slew of
requirements challenges around
resiliency and consequently the way
chaos engineering is practiced
despite the fact that its
actual philosophy remains same
this working group aims to establish
chaos engineering as an important
practice and a go-to mechanism
to enforce resiliency in the application
delivery world
by identifying trends
developing patterns
documenting best practices highlighting
user stories from the real world
all this while being tool and vendor
neutral
it is comprised of a diverse
cross-functional group with members from

chaos chaos blade and others

and observability
members from the practitioner and end
